Is the ripening of that karma not yet free from defilements?
And so on at length.
Question: Why was this treatise composed?
Answer: In order to stop the tenets of others and reveal one's own meaning.
Namely, the VÄtsÄ«putrÄ«ya school says that the five types of karma
also generally belong to the five types in terms of the ripening they obtain.
In order to stop their intention and reveal that although karma generally belongs to the five types, its ripening is only eliminated by cultivation, this treatise is composed.
If karma is not yet free from defilements,
is the ripening of that karma not yet free from defilements?
Answer: All karma that is not yet free from defilements,
the ripening of that karma is definitely not yet free from defilements.
There may be the ripening of karma that is not yet free from defilements,
but that karma has already been freed from defilements.
Namely, for a stream-enterer, karma eliminated by the path of seeing has already been freed from defilements.
The ripening of that karma is not yet free from defilements.ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:
It should be known that in this case, there may be karma that is first separated from defilements,
but the retribution is only later separated from defilements.
There may be karma whose retribution is separated from defilements at the same time.
There is definitely no retribution that first attains separation from defilements,
and later that karma attains separation from defilements.
That is to say, at the time of the four dharma forbearances,
it causes the unwholesome karma included in the four categories to first attain separation from defilements.
It is not their retribution.
Also, at the time of the first eight uninterrupted paths before separating from the defilements of the desire realm,
it causes the unwholesome karma to be eliminated through cultivation in the first eight categories to first attain separation from defilements.
It is not their retribution.
Those retributions must attain separation from defilements at the time of the ninth uninterrupted path.
This is called karma that is first separated from defilements,
and later its retribution attains separation from defilements.
At the time of the ninth uninterrupted path of separating from the defilements of the desire realm,
it causes the unwholesome karma in the ninth category
and all the unwholesome bodily and verbal karma,
and the wholesome karma of the desire realm,
and the corresponding karmic retribution are simultaneously abandoned.
When abandoning the defilements of the first dhyÄna, at the time of the ninth uninterrupted path,
it causes the karma of the first dhyÄna and its corresponding karmic retribution to be simultaneously abandoned.
In this way, up to abandoning the defilements of the sphere of neither-perception-nor-non-perception,
at the time of the ninth uninterrupted path,
it causes the karma of the sphere of neither-perception-nor-non-perception
and its corresponding karmic retribution to be simultaneously abandoned.
This is called karma and its corresponding karmic retribution being simultaneously abandoned.
As for non-form and unwholesome karma,
it is also categorized as the five parts and is severed by the nine grades of the path.
As for all unwholesome form karma,
contaminated wholesome karma,
and all karmic retribution,
they are only severed by the path of cultivation.
They are only severed by the highest grade of the superior path.
This is called the brief discussion of this point.
However, in this case, the treatise is composed based on two kinds of karma,
namely, that which is severed by insight and that which is severed by cultivation. This is said.
If the treatise is composed based on five kinds of karma,
Then one should not say that it refers to the karma to be eliminated by seeing of the stream-enterer,
and so on in detail.
One should say:
It refers to one who has not yet eliminated the passion of desire.
When the knowledge of suffering has arisen but the knowledge of accumulation has not yet arisen,
the karma to be eliminated by seeing suffering has already been eliminated,
but the retribution of that karma has not yet been eliminated.
When the knowledge of accumulation has arisen but the knowledge of cessation has not yet arisen,
the karma to be eliminated by seeing suffering and accumulation has already been eliminated,
but the retribution of that karma has not yet been eliminated.
When the knowledge of cessation has arisen but the knowledge of the path has not yet arisen,
the karma to be eliminated by seeing suffering, accumulation, and cessation has already been eliminated,
but the retribution of that karma has not yet been eliminated.
When the knowledge of the path has arisen but one has not yet eliminated the passion of the desire realm,
the karma to be eliminated by seeing suffering, accumulation, cessation, and the path has already been eliminated,
but the retribution of that karma has not yet been eliminated.
When one has eliminated one stage of the passion of the desire realm,
up to the eighth stage,
the eighth stage of karma has already been eliminated,
but the retribution of that karma has not yet been eliminated.
When one is in the ninth uninterrupted path of detachment from the desire realm,
that ninth category of karma,
all unwholesome bodily and verbal karma,
wholesome karma of the desire realm,
and their respective karmic maturations are simultaneously detached from defilements.
When one is in the ninth uninterrupted path of detachment from the first dhyÄna up to the sphere of neither-perception-nor-non-perception,
the wholesome karma of all stages and their respective karmic maturations are simultaneously detached from defilements.
But this is not stated.
Because the treatise is based on two kinds of karma.
If karma is already detached from defilements,
is that karma's karmic maturation also already detached from defilements?
The answer is: All karma whose karmic maturation is already detached from defilements, that karma is definitely already detached from defilements.
There may be karma that is already detached from defilements,
but whose karmic maturation is not yet detached from defilements.
This refers to karma to be experienced in the present life by a stream-enterer that is to be eliminated by seeing, whose karmic maturation is not yet detached from defilements.
Here, the distinctions are explained in detail as before.
If karma has results,
does that karma all have karmic maturations?
And so on, explaining in detail.
Question: Why is this treatise composed?
Answer: In order to stop heterodox schools and reveal the correct principle.
There are non-Buddhists who hold that all good and evil karma have no fruition or ripening.
In order to stop their views and show that all karma has fruition,
because all contaminated good and evil karma have ripening. Thus this treatise is composed.
However, in the sutras it is said:
There are five kinds of fruits.
1. Retribution fruit.
2. Ripened fruit.
3. Fruit of separation.
4. Fruit of human effort.
5. Dominant fruit.
As for the retribution fruit,
it means good giving rise to good,
evil giving rise to evil,
indeterminate giving rise to indeterminate.
As for the ripened fruit,
it refers to the ripening caused by unwholesome and contaminated wholesome dharmas.
This good and evil fruit is only indeterminate,
because it ripens as a different category, it is called the ripened fruit.
As for the fruit of separation,
it refers to the severing of afflictions by the uninterrupted path.
This uninterrupted path,
with the elimination of afflictions, etc., as its disjunction effect.
And as its human effort effect.
With the liberation path as its outflow effect.
And as its human effort effect.
With subsequent similar superior paths as its outflow effect.
If it is an uninterrupted path,
it is able to realize the accumulation of previously eliminated afflictions.
This uninterrupted path, with the elimination of those afflictions,
only has the human effort effect.
This is the general explanation.
If the specific explanation is given,
the receptivity to the cognition of the factors of the path,
with the elimination of the ten latent afflictions, etc., eliminated by seeing the truth of suffering in the desire realm,
as its disjunction effect.
And as its human effort effect.
With the category of cognition of the factors of the path as its outflow effect.
And as its human effort effect.
With subsequent similar superior pure paths as its outflow effect.
In this way, up to the receptivity to the cognition of the class of the path,
with the elimination of the afflictions of the form and formless realms,
The abandonment of the fourteen latent afflictions and so on that are eliminated by the path of seeing is the effect of disjunction.
And it is also the effect of human effort.
The class of the path of insight into the truth of the path is the effect of outflow.
And it is also the effect of human effort.
The subsequent pure paths that are equal or superior are the effect of outflow.
The abandonment of the latent afflictions and so on that are eliminated by seeing the truths of suffering, origination, and cessation in the three realms,
and the abandonment of the latent afflictions and so on that are eliminated by seeing the truth of the path in the desire realm, are all accumulated and attained as evidence.
This acceptance of the class of the path of insight into the truth of the path
is the effect of human effort of those abandonments.
All stream-enterers
when seeking to realize the fruit of once-returning
the first five uninterrupted paths
the abandonment of the five categories of latent afflictions and so on
is the effect of disjunction and the effect of human effort.
The five paths of liberation
are the effect of outflow and the effect of human effort.
The subsequent paths of the same kind that are equal or superior are the effect of outflow.
The sixth uninterrupted path abandons the sixth category of latent afflictions and so on
is the effect of disjunction and the effect of human effort.
The sixth path of liberation takes the homogeneous cause and the effect of human effort as its effect.

The subsequent, equal, and superior paths of the same type take the homogeneous cause as their effect.ğŸ”½The three realms of views to be eliminated, and the first five categories of the afflictions to be eliminated through cultivation in the desire realm,
are eliminated and the attainment of realization is accomplished.
This sixth uninterrupted path,
takes the elimination of those afflictions as the effect of human effort.
For those who are once-returners,
when seeking to realize the fruit of non-returning,
the uninterrupted path arises and is able to eliminate the four latent afflictions to be eliminated through cultivation in the desire realm.
If the seventh and eighth categories are eliminated,
this uninterrupted path,
takes the elimination of those two categories of latent afflictions,
as the effect of separation and the effect of human effort.
The two paths of liberation take the homogeneous cause and the effect of human effort as their effects.
The subsequent, equal, and superior paths of the same type,
take the homogeneous cause as their effect.ğŸ”½If the ninth category is eliminated, the single uninterrupted path,
takes the elimination of the ninth category of latent afflictions,
It is the effect of disjunction and the effect of human effort.
With the ninth path of liberation,
it is the effect of natural outflow and the effect of human effort.
With the subsequent paths of the same type that are equal or superior,
it is the effect of natural outflow.

With the cessation of the abandonment of the defilements to be eliminated by the path of seeing in the three realms and the first eight categories of defilements to be eliminated by cultivation in the desire realm,
one attains realization.
This ninth uninterrupted path,
with those abandonments as the effect of human effort.
For those who are non-returners,
when seeking to realize the fruit of arhatship,
the uninterrupted path arises, able to eliminate the six latent defilements to be eliminated by cultivation in the formless realm.
If one eliminates the first category of defilements of the first trance state,
up to the ninth category,
these nine uninterrupted paths,
with the abandonment of those nine categories of latent defilements,
are the effect of disjunction and the effect of human effort.
With the nine paths of liberation, they are the effect of natural outflow and the effect of human effort.
With the subsequent paths of the same type that are equal or superior, they are the effect of natural outflow.
In this way, up to being free from the defilements of the sphere of neither-perception-nor-non-perception.
The first eight uninterrupted paths
with the abandonment of those eight classes of latent afflictions, etc.
are the fruit of separation and the fruit of human effort.
With the eight liberated paths, they are the fruit of outflow and the fruit of human effort.
With the subsequent superior pure paths,
they are the fruit of outflow.
The diamond-like concentration, with the abandonment of the ninth class of latent afflictions, etc.,
is the fruit of separation and the fruit of human effort.
With the first class of knowledge of elimination, it is the fruit of outflow and the fruit of human effort.
With the subsequent superior pure paths,
it is the fruit of outflow.
With the abandonment of the seen and cultivated [afflictions] of the three realms, and the first eight classes of afflictions to be eliminated by cultivation in the lower eight stages,
not the sphere of neither-perception-nor-non-perception,
the accumulation of the abandonment of the first eight classes of latent afflictions, etc.,
is attained.
This diamond-like concentration, with those abandonments as the fruit of human effort,
if ordinary beings are free from the desire realm up to the sphere of nothingness,
The uninterrupted paths of defilements to be eliminated by the path of seeing and cultivation.
The paths of liberation of those eliminations.
And the subsequent, equal, and superior paths of the same type.
Are the fruits.
The number of each should be considered according to reason.
As for the effect of human effort,
if a dharma is accomplished by human effort,
it is said to be the effect of human effort.
As for the dominant effect,
if a dharma is produced by the dominant condition,
it should be known that this dharma is the dominant condition and the dominant effect.
The remaining dominant conditions are not dominant effects.
Namely, the subsequently arisen dharmas are the dominant conditions and dominant effects of the preceding dharmas.
The preceding dharmas
are the dominant conditions but not the dominant effects of the subsequent dharmas.
The future dharmas
are the dominant conditions and dominant effects of the past and present dharmas.
The past and present dharmas
are the dominant conditions but not the dominant effects of the future dharmas.
The future and present dharmas
are the dominant conditions of the past dharmas.
and dominant fruit.ğŸ”½Past dharmas
are the dominant conditions for future and present dharmas.
They are not dominant fruits.
Question: What is the difference between the human effort fruit and the dominant fruit?
Answer: All things that are done
are the human effort fruit and the dominant fruit for the doer.
For the experiencer, they are only the dominant fruit.
For example, all things that are done, such as farming, are the human effort fruit and the dominant fruit for farmers.
For the enjoyer, they are only the dominant fruit.ğŸ”½Arising from the power of human effort is called the human effort fruit.
Arising from the dominant power is called the dominant fruit.
The dominant power is broad because it does not obstruct.
The power of human effort is narrow because it can lead to realization.
This is called the difference between the two fruits.
Western masters say that there are nine kinds of fruits.
That is, in addition to the previous five, four more are added.
First, the established fruit.
Second, the practice fruit.
Third, the combined fruit.
Fourth, the cultivated fruit.
As for the established fruit,
it refers to the fact that the water wheel is established based on the wind wheel,
and the gold wheel is established based on the water wheel,
and the great earth is established based on the gold wheel,
and all sentient and non-sentient things are established based on the great earth.
Here, the latter is the fruit of the former.
The other established fruits should be understood in this way.
As for the fruit of application,
it refers to the fact that the contemplation of impurity
or mindfulness of breathing
is the application.
Therefore, it gradually gives rise to the knowledge of extinction and non-arising.
The other fruits of application should be understood in this way.
As for the fruit of combination,
it refers to the fact that eye and form combine to give rise to eye consciousness,
and mind and dharmas combine to give rise to mental consciousness.
The other fruits of combination should be understood in this way.
As for the fruit of cultivation,
it refers to the fact that the path of the form realm gives rise to transformations and speech of the desire realm.
This transformation and speech
are the fruit of cultivation.
The other fruits of cultivation are also like this.
The Abhidharma masters of KaÅ›mÄ«ra say:
The last four are included in the first five.
Because they are the results of human effort and predominance.
One should know that the worldly path of practice and the path of cultivation have results.
They are called having results because they are endowed with the five results.
The path of preparation, the path of liberation, and the path of advancement have results.
And the other unwholesome and wholesome contaminated actions
are called having results because they have four results.
Excluding the result of disentanglement.
If the uncontaminated path of practice has results,
it is also called having results because it has four results.
Excluding the result of karmic maturation. The path of preparation, the path of liberation, and the path of advancement
and indeterminate actions
are called having results because they have three results.
Excluding the result of disentanglement and the result of karmic maturation.
This is called the brief discussion of this topic.
If an action has results, does that action all have karmic maturation?
Answer: Those actions that have karmic maturation
all have results.
One should know that this action
may be by the five results.
Or by the four fruits.
It is said to have fruits.
Or there are actions that have fruits.
But those actions have no retribution.ğŸ”½It refers to indeterminate actions.
And pure actions.
It should be known that this action is either by the four fruits.
Or by the three fruits.
It is said to have fruits.
However, it has no retribution because it is not solid.
Because it is not moistened by craving.
If an action has no fruit, does that action have no retribution?
The answer is: There is no action that has no fruit.
It refers to all actions, which are either by the five fruits.
Or by the four fruits.
Or by the three fruits.
Because it is said to have fruits.
Or there are actions that have no retribution.ğŸ”½It refers to indeterminate actions.
And pure actions.
As explained above.
If all actions have fruits,
how can we understand the verse spoken by the Buddha?
It says:
Although a flower may be lovely, it has color but no fragrance.
In the same way, there may be beautiful words, but they have no fruit and no effect.
Answer: It is based on the expounder of the Dharma that the Buddha spoke this verse.
That is to say, when expounding the Dharma, the listener
is unable to accept it in faith and practice it as taught.
This is called having no fruit.
Or, even though the expounder of the Dharma may expound it well,
he is unable to practice it, so it is said to have no fruit.
Or, having previously promised to give something to another,
he is unable to bestow it, so it is said to have no fruit.
Question: How can we understand the other sÅ«tras?
As it is said:
Having life, pleasure, dullness, and sleep, empty, fruitless, and meaningless,
Without flavor, without benefit, utterly without arising.
Answer: When one is awake, one is able to attain superior virtues.
Because of delighting in sleep, one passes over this time in vain.
The World-Honored One, based on this, spoke this verse.
Question: If delighting in sleep is empty and fruitless,
how can we understand what is said in other sÅ«tras?
As it is said:
It is better to sleep than to have other discursive thoughts.
Answer: When one is awake, one gives rise to evil discursive thoughts.
Causing immeasurable sentient beings to be disturbed by disputes.
The Buddha warned them about this and said it.
For this reason, the sutra has a separate meaning.
It does not mean that all karma is completely without results.
If karma is unwholesome, is that karma all inverted?
The answer is that four sentences should be made.
There is karma that is unwholesome but that karma is not inverted.
This refers to someone who sees that there is cause and effect.
They give rise to such a view.
They establish such a theory.
There is karma and the ripening of the results of karma, yet they engage in physical, verbal, and mental evil deeds.
What is the reason for their engaging in evil deeds?
The answer is that there are three reasons.
First, due to time.
Second, due to place.
Third, due to the person.
As for due to time,
It refers to the time when the five turbidities increase, and the spiritual powers of sentient beings decrease, and they happily create all kinds of evil.
Because they are in that time, they also engage in evil deeds.
As for due to place,
It refers to sentient beings born among cotton-growers and mleccha people.
Their nature is foolish and vulgar, often creating evil karma.
Because they are born in that place, they also engage in evil conduct.
As for the reason of the person,
there is a type that obtains the common destiny of evil conduct.
Their nature is fierce and violent, often creating evil karma.
Like butchers of sheep and others who are not disciplined.
Because of associating with them, they also engage in evil conduct.
It should be known that this karma is called unwholesome by nature.
Because it is included in evil conduct of body, speech, and mind.
By the reason of the basis, it is called non-inverted.
It is the view of action, not ignorant of cause and effect.
Because it is equally produced in the body of right view.
Like feces and filth contained in a precious vessel.
There is karma that is inverted, but that karma is not unwholesome.
It is like someone who does not see cause and effect.
Gives rise to such a view.
Establishes such a doctrine.
There is no karma, no karma and its result to be experienced.
Yet practices good conduct of body, speech, and mind.
Why do they practice good conduct?
The answer is: for three reasons.
First, by time.
Second, by place.
Third, by the person.ğŸ”½By time means
at the time when the five turbidities are not increasing,
all sentient beings have great authority and power,
liking to cultivate various good deeds, being in that time.
Even if they do not enjoy doing it, they still practice good conduct.
By place means
being born in the central country, all sentient beings
are by nature intelligent and their minds are pliable,
often cultivating good deeds, being born in that place.
Even if they do not enjoy doing it, they still practice good conduct.
By the person means
there is a type of person who obtains the good conduct of the same group,
their nature is harmonious and elegant, often cultivating good deeds,
like those who abide by the precepts, being close to them.
Even if they do not enjoy doing it, they still practice good conduct.
It should be known that this karma is said to be upside-down by its basis.
This view of non-action is ignorant of cause and effect.
Because it arises equally in the body of wrong view.
By its very nature, it is called not unwholesome.
Because it is included in the good conduct of body, speech, and mind.
Like precious treasures stored in a filthy vessel.
There is karma that is both unwholesome and inverted.
For example, if someone sees no cause and effect,
they give rise to such a view.
They establish such a doctrine, saying there is no karma, no result of karma, and no ripening of karma.
And they engage in evil conduct of body, speech, and mind.
Question: For what reason do they engage in evil conduct?
Answer: For three reasons, as explained before.
It should be known that this karma is called unwholesome by its very nature.
Because it is included in the evil conduct of body, speech, and mind.
By its basis, it is also called inverted.
This view of non-action is ignorant of cause and effect.
Because it arises equally in the body of wrong view.
Like filth stored in a filthy vessel.
There is karma that is neither unwholesome nor inverted.
It is like someone who sees cause and effect.
They give rise to such a view.
They establish such a doctrine.
There is karma and there is the ripening of karma and its effects.
They also practice good conduct of body, speech, and mind.
Why do they practice good conduct?
The answer is: for three reasons, as explained before.
It should be known that this karma is called not unwholesome by nature.
Because it is included in the good conduct of body, speech, and mind.
It is called not inverted by basis.
This is the view of action, not ignorant of cause and effect.
Because it arises equally in the body and so on of right view.
It is like precious treasures contained in a precious vessel.
If an action is good, is that action not inverted?
The answer is: four sentences should be made.ğŸ”½That is, the second sentence above becomes the first sentence here.
The first sentence above becomes the second sentence here.
The fourth sentence above becomes the third sentence here.
The third sentence above becomes the fourth sentence here.
It is explained in detail as before.
Furthermore, there is another explanation for this.
If an action is unwholesome, is that action all inverted?
The answer should be made in four sentences.
There is an action that is unwholesome but that action is not inverted.
This refers to a case where someone, regarding what is seen, has the notion of not seeing.
When asked by another, Did you see?
Whether for oneself,
for others,
or for fame and profit,
one conceals this notion, this forbearance, this view, and this desire.
The answer is,
I saw.
It should be known that this action is called unwholesome by the power of the notion.
Because it is said to conceal the notion.
By the matter spoken of, it is called non-inverted.
Because it is said to see what is seen.
There is an action that is inverted but that action is not unwholesome.
This refers to a case where someone, regarding what is seen, has the notion of not seeing.
When asked by another,
Did you see?
He does not do it for himself,
not for others,
not for fame and profit,
and does not conceal this notion, this forbearance, this view, and this desire.
He replied:
I did not see.
It should be known that this karma is called inverted due to the matter spoken of.
Because he said he did not see what he saw.
It is called not unwholesome due to the power of thought.
Because he spoke with a thought of concealment.
There is karma that is both unwholesome and inverted.
It is like when someone has seen something and has the thought of having seen it.
Another asks him:
Did you see it or not?
He may do this for himself,
for others,
or for fame and profit.
He then conceals this thought, this forbearance, this view, and this desire.
He replies:
I did not see. It should be known that this karma is called unwholesome due to the power of thought.
Because he spoke with a thought of concealment. It is called inverted due to the matter spoken of.
Because he said he did not see what he saw.
There is karma that is neither unwholesome nor inverted.
It is like when someone has seen something and has the thought of having seen it.
Another asks him:
Did you see it or not? He does not do this for himself,
not for others,
Not for fame or profit.
Not concealing this thought, this forbearance, this view, this desire.
Answer:
I see.
It should be known that this karma is called non-unwholesome due to the power of thought.
Because it is said with the thought of non-concealment.
It is called non-inverted due to the matter being spoken of, because it is said that one sees what one has seen.
As there are four propositions regarding what is seen,
so there are also four propositions regarding what is heard, cognized, and known.
As there are four propositions regarding each of what is seen, heard, cognized, and known,
so there are also four propositions regarding each of what is not seen, not heard, not cognized, and not known.
As there are eight propositions with four propositions each by contrasting unwholesomeness with inversion,
so it should be known that by contrasting wholesomeness with non-inversion,
this then forms sixteen propositions with four propositions each.
And the previous two propositions with four propositions each form eighteen propositions with four propositions each.
Furthermore, the nine small propositions with four propositions each of unwholesomeness,
and the nine small propositions with four propositions each of wholesomeness,
each form one large proposition with four propositions each.
Therefore, there are a total of twenty-four sentences, general and specific.
Here, what is received by eye consciousness is called seeing.
What is received by ear consciousness is called hearing.
What is received by the three consciousnesses is called cognition.
What is received by mental consciousness is called knowing.
Because the four objects are spoken of, there is seeing, hearing, cognition, and knowing.
These are faculties, not consciousnesses. However, in mentioning consciousness, it is shown that the eye and other faculties can only apprehend objects by the assistance of consciousness.
Because the homogeneous faculties can have function, not their non-homogeneous counterparts.
Why are the three consciousnesses received by the eye, etc. each established as one kind,
while the three consciousnesses received by the nose, tongue, and body,
are combined and established as one kind called cognition?
Venerable Vasumitra said:
The objects of the three consciousnesses are all only indeterminate.
Because the objects are indeterminate, the faculties are established with the name cognition.
Moreover, the three faculties only apprehend objects that have arrived.
Because they combine with the objects, they are established with the name cognition.
The Venerable One said:
Only these three faculties have dull and dim objects, just like corpses.
Therefore, when consciousness arises, it is called cognition.
Other masters say:
The two consciousnesses of eye and ear rely on their own realm and take their own and other realms as objects.
Mental consciousness relies on its own and other realms.
Because it takes its own and other realms as objects, each is established as one kind.
The three consciousnesses of nose, etc. only rely on their own realm and only take their own realm as objects.
Therefore, what they experience is combined into one kind.
As for the same realm and different realms, the same and different classes, it is said to be the same.
Other masters say:
The two consciousnesses of eye and ear rely on the same class.
They take the same and different classes as objects.
Mental consciousness relies on the same and different classes.
It takes the same and different classes as objects.
Therefore, what it experiences is established as one kind.
The three consciousnesses of nose, etc. only rely on the same class.
They only take the same class as objects.
Therefore, what they experience is combined into one kind.
This is said to be the same realm.
Some say:
The two consciousnesses of eye and ear rely on the indeterminate and take three kinds as objects.
Mental consciousness relies on three kinds and takes three kinds as objects.
Therefore, the feelings they experience are established as one kind each.
The three consciousnesses of nose, etc. only rely on the indeterminate and only take the indeterminate as objects.
Therefore, the feelings they experience are combined and established as one kind.
Some say:
The two consciousnesses of eye and ear rely on the near and take the near as objects, and the far as objects.
The mental consciousness relies on the near and far and takes the near and far as objects.
Therefore, the feelings they experience are established as one kind each.
The three consciousnesses of nose, etc. rely on the near and take the near as objects.
Therefore, the feelings they experience are combined and established as one kind.
These three faculties and objects abide without interval.
Only then can they give rise to consciousness, therefore,
they are called near.
Some say:
The two consciousnesses of eye and ear may have a small faculty as support and a large object,
a large faculty as support and a small object,
or a faculty and object of equal size.
The eye consciousness having a small faculty as support and a large object means
seeing the tip of a hair, etc.
Having a large object and a small faculty as support means seeing a mountain, etc.
Having a faculty and object of equal size means
seeing a grape fruit, etc.
The same should be understood for the ear consciousness.
Although the basis of the mental consciousness cannot be said to have a size,
the objects it perceives are sometimes small and sometimes large.
Therefore, the feelings it experiences are established as being of one kind each.
The three consciousnesses of the nose, etc., have the same size for their basis and objects.
Therefore, the feelings they experience are combined and established as being of one kind.
According to the number of atoms that make up the sense organs that are their basis,
when they combine with that many atoms of objects,
they are then able to give rise to the nose consciousness, etc.
Some say:
The three consciousnesses of the eye, etc., perceive both karma and what is not karma.
Therefore, the feelings they experience are established as being of one kind each.
The three consciousnesses of the nose, etc., only perceive what is not karma.
Therefore, the feelings they experience are combined and established as being of one kind.
Some say:
The three consciousnesses of the eye, etc.,
perceive both the observance of precepts and the violation of precepts, as well as other dharmas.
Therefore, the feelings they experience are established as being of one kind each.
The three consciousnesses of the nose, etc., only perceive other dharmas.
Therefore, the feelings they experience are combined and established as being of one kind.
Other masters say:
The three consciousnesses of the eye, etc.
Universally take the precepts, the non-precepts, and other dharmas as objects.
Therefore, the precepts they receive are established as each being one kind.
The three consciousnesses of the nose, etc. only take other dharmas as objects.
Therefore, the precepts they receive are combined and established as one kind.
Some say:
The three consciousnesses of the eye, etc. universally take the expressed and other dharmas as objects.
Therefore, the precepts they receive are established as each being one kind.
The three consciousnesses of the nose, etc. only take other dharmas as objects.
Therefore, the precepts they receive are combined and established as one kind.
Some say:
The three consciousnesses of the eye, etc. universally take defiled and undefiled dharmas as objects.
Therefore, the precepts they receive are established as each being one kind.
The three consciousnesses of the nose, etc. only take the undefiled as objects.
Therefore, the precepts they receive are combined and established as one kind.
Some say:
The three consciousnesses of the eye, etc.
Universally take right conduct, wrong conduct, and other dharmas as objects.
Therefore, the precepts they receive are established as each being one kind.
The three consciousnesses of the nose, etc. only take other dharmas as objects.
Therefore, the precepts they receive are combined and established as one kind.
Therefore, what is said about seeing, hearing, knowing, and perceiving,
according to the basis and objects of the consciousnesses, there are distinctions and general categories.
If one possesses unwholesome karma,
do they possess karma bound to the form and formless realms?
The answer is: Those who possess unwholesome karma,
they definitely possess karma bound to the form and formless realms.
This refers to those born in the desire realm who have severed wholesome roots.
They definitely possess unwholesome karma,
and one karma bound to the form and formless realms,
namely defiled karma.
Those who have not severed wholesome roots but have not yet attained wholesome thoughts of the form realm are also like this.
If one has already attained wholesome thoughts of the form realm,
but has not yet become free from the defilements of the desire realm,
they possess unwholesome karma,
and two karmas bound to the form realm,
namely wholesome and defiled.
One karma bound to the formless realm,
namely defiled.
There are those who possess karma bound to the form and formless realms but not unwholesome karma.
This refers to those born in the desire realm who have already become free from the defilements of the desire realm,
or those born in the form realm.
It refers to those born in the desire realm who have already separated from the defilements of the desire realm.
If they have not yet attained a wholesome mind of the formless realm,
they possess three kinds of actions bound to the form realm,
namely wholesome, defiled, and unobscured indeterminate.
They possess one kind of action bound to the formless realm,
namely defiled.
If they have already attained a wholesome mind of the formless realm,
but have not yet separated from the defilements of the form realm,
they possess three kinds of actions bound to the form realm,
namely wholesome, defiled, and unobscured indeterminate.
They possess two kinds of actions bound to the formless realm,
namely wholesome and defiled.
If they have already separated from the defilements of the form realm,
but have not yet separated from the defilements of the formless realm,
they possess two kinds of actions bound to the form realm,
namely wholesome and unobscured indeterminate.
They possess two kinds of actions bound to the formless realm,
namely wholesome and defiled.
If they have already separated from the defilements of the formless realm,
they possess two kinds of actions bound to the form realm,
namely wholesome and unobscured indeterminate.
They possess one kind of action bound to the formless realm,
namely wholesome.
As for those born in the form realm,
If one has not yet attained a wholesome mind of the formless realm,
one possesses three kinds of actions bound to the form realm,
namely wholesome, defiled, and unwholesome indeterminate.
One possesses one kind of action bound to the formless realm,
namely defiled.
If one has already attained a wholesome mind of the formless realm,
but has not yet separated from attachment to the form realm,
one possesses three kinds of actions bound to the form realm,
namely wholesome, defiled, and unwholesome indeterminate.
One possesses two kinds of actions bound to the formless realm,

If one has already separated from attachment to the form realm,
but has not yet separated from attachment to the formless realm,
one possesses two kinds of actions bound to the form realm,

One possesses two kinds of actions bound to the formless realm,

If one has already separated from attachment to the formless realm,
one possesses two kinds of actions bound to the form realm,
namely wholesome and unwholesome indeterminate.
One possesses one kind of action bound to the formless realm,
